ref_item.label: Conventional radiofrequency (RF) treatment
ref_item.description: All patients with chronic knee pain who qualify for a conventional RF treatment of the genicular nerves

pred_item.label: PPSP Group
pred_item.description: Patients diagnosed with persistent post-surgical pain (PPSP), primarily after total knee arthroplasty (TKA), suffering from chronic anterior knee pain.
interventionNames: Procedure: Ultrasound-guided conventional radiofrequency (RF) treatment of the genicular nerves

ref_item.measure: The Number of Patients Reaching Treatment Succes at 6 Weeks Defined as Global Perceived Effect (GPE) of ≥ 50% Compared to Baseline.
ref_item.description:
Treatment success is defined as a global perceived effect (GPE) of at least 50% at measurement time point compared to baseline.

Global perceived effect (GPE) scales are used as an overall outcome measure for patients with pain, as they may cover additional aspects to pain relief and physical function that are important to the individual. Patients are asked to response on the question of how the treatment influenced the pain symptoms. The patients were asked to expres their answer in percentage where 0 % ( no improvement) to 100 (total improvement, the symptoms are gone).

pred_item.measure: Proportion of patients with treatment success
pred_item.description: Treatment success defined as a Global Perceived Effect (GPE) of ≥50% compared to baseline.

ref_item.measure: The Number of Participants With NRS Reduction ≥50% Compared to Baseline
ref_item.description:
The numeric rating scale (NRS) is used to assess pain intensity varying from 0 (no pain) to 10 (intense pain). This scale was retrieved retrospectively out of the patient file.

NRS reduction ≥50% is calculated using the NRS at 6 weeks compared to the NRS at baseline.

pred_item.description: Proportion of patients with NRS reduction ≥50% compared to baseline.
pred_item.timeFrame: Week 6 and at the second time point

ref_item.description: The numeric rating scale (NRS) is used to assess pain intensity varying from 0 (no pain) to 10 (intense pain). This scale will be asked telephonically to the patient.
ref_item.timeFrame: after retrieval of informed consent, ranging from 6 weeks to 2.5 years after the procedure

pred_item.description: Defined as the period with pain reduction.

ref_item.measure: The Number of Patients With Subjective Increase in Physical Functioning at the Second Time Point
ref_item.description: The question 'Do you experience at the moment functional improvement in comparison with before the treatment?' is asked telephonically to the patient. The possible answers are 'no increase in physical functioning' and ' yes, there was an increase in physical funcitoning'. An increase in physical functioning is the best outcome.
ref_item.timeFrame: after retrieval of informed consent, ranging from 6 weeks to 2.5 years after the procedure

pred_item.description: Subjective functional outcome assessed via questionnaire.

ref_item.measure: The Number of Pariticipants Using Strong Opioids
ref_item.description: The change in use of strong opioids is retrieved retrospectively out of the patient file. The answer to the use of strong opioids is yes or no. No use of strong opioids is a better outcome.

ref_item.measure: Strong Opioid Use at the Second Time Point
ref_item.description: The change in use of strong opioids is asked telephonically to the patient.
ref_item.timeFrame: after retrieval of informed consent, ranging from 6 weeks to 2.5 years after the procedure

pred_item.description: Evaluation of the change in use of strong opioids.
pred_item.timeFrame: Week 6 and at the second time point

ref_item.measure: The Number of Participants Reaching Treatment Success After Retrieval of the Informed Consent Defined as GPE of ≥ 50% Compared to Baseline.
ref_item.description:
Treatment success is defined as a global perceived effect (GPE) of at least 50% at measurement time point compared to baseline.

Global perceived effect (GPE) scales are used as an overall outcome measure for patients with pain, as they may cover additional aspects to pain relief and physical function that are important to the individual. Patients are asked to response on the question of how the treatment influenced the pain symptoms. The patients were asked to expres their answer in percentage where 0 % ( no improvement) to 100 (total improvement, the symptoms are gone).
ref_item.timeFrame: after retrieval of informed consent, ranging from 6 weeks to 2.5 years after the procedure

pred_item.measure: Proportion of patients with treatment success at follow-up
pred_item.description: Treatment success defined as a GPE of ≥50% compared to baseline.
pred_item.timeFrame: Second time point (variable follow-up, mean 17 months)

ref_item.measure: Number of Participants With Post-treatment Complications
ref_item.description: Adverse events related to the conventional radiofrequency therapy will be assessed. This will be assessed retrospectively in the patient file according to the standard of care consultation at 6 weeks after treatment.

pred_item.description: Number, type, and severity of adverse events.
pred_item.timeFrame: Week 6 and at the second time point

ref_item.measure: Number of Participants With Post-treatment Complications
ref_item.description: Adverse events related to the conventional radiofrequency therapy will be assessed telephonically
ref_item.timeFrame: after retrieval of informed consent, ranging from 6 weeks to 2.5 years after the procedure
